text:
If the legality of a move cannot be determined with finality, or if by the Judge’s best reasoning, not
overruled, a move appears equally legal and illegal, then the player whose move is in question is
the winner. If the rules are changed so that further play is impossible, the player who’s allocated
day it is the winner.
This rule takes precedence over every other rule determining the winner.

notes.author: Ben
notes.content: The voting procedure is described in Rule 113.

notes.author: Ben
notes.content: Only rule-changes that are in accordance with Rule 202 will be voted on.

notes.author: Ben
notes.content:
The proposer may choose to submit a draft version of the rule-change to the Telegram discussion
thread. There other players may suggest amendments or argue against the proposal.

text:
A rule-change is proposed by submitting it in text form preceded by the words “Rule-change:” to
the Telegram voting thread, after which it may not be modified or withdrawn.
The proposer decides the form of the proposal is to be voted on. If they are adopted, they shall
guide play in the form in which they were voted on.

Rule-changes that affect rules needed to allow or apply rule-changes are as permissible as other
rule-changes. Even rule-changes that amend or repeal their own authority are permissible. No rule-change or type of move is impermissible solely on account of the self-reference or self-application
of a rule.

notes.author: Ben
notes.content:
This definition implies that, at least initially, all new rules are mutable; immutable rules, as long
as they are immutable, may not be amended or repealed; mutable rules, as long as they are mutable, may be amended or repealed; any rule of any status may be transmuted; no rule is absolutely immune
to change.

text:
A rule-change is any of the following: (1) the enactment, repeal, or amendment of a mutable
rule; (2) the enactment, repeal, or amendment of an amendment of a mutable rule; or (3) the
transmutation of an immutable rule into a mutable rule or vice versa.
Every player is an eligible voter.
All times specified in rules in UK time. Days are considered to start and end in UK time.

notes.author: Ben
notes.content: Completion of the vote is defined in Rule 113

text:
A rule-change is adopted if and only if a simple majority of the votes cast by the time of completion of the vote are in favour of the rule-change; unless the rule-change transmutes a rule (either an immutable rule into a mutable rule, or a mutable rule into an immutable rule), in which case the vote must be unanimous among the votes cast by the time of completion of the vote. Transmutation shall not be implied, but must be
stated explicitly in a proposal to take effect.

notes.author: Ben
notes.content: Rule 309 -> Rule 313 on day 017.

notes.author: Ben
notes.content: Rule 109 -> Rule 309 on day 012.

text: If the number of a rule is changed, due to Rule 313 or otherwise, any reference to that rule number is also changed.

In a conflict between a mutable and an immutable rule, the immutable rule takes precedence and
the mutable rule shall be entirely void. For the purposes of this rule a proposal to transmute an
immutable rule does not "conflict" with that immutable rule.

notes.author: Ben
notes.content:
The Judge may seek to open discussions on a Point of Order, for example within the discussion thread,
prior to submitting their Judgement.

notes.author: Ben
notes.content:
As multiple Points of Order can be decided on simultaneously, overruling can lead to distinct
Judges deciding on multiple Judgements simultaneously.

text: If players disagree about the legality of a move or the interpretation or application of a rule, then any player may call for a Judgement on the decision. They do so by entering a message into the Telegram voting thread of the form “Point of Order:” followed by a description of the statement to be judged. The player whose allocated day preceded the current day is to be the Judge and decide the question. After considering the statement, they pronounce their verdict by typing “Judgement:” followed by their decision into the Telegram voting chat. This must reference the original Point of Order. Following the pronouncement, there is a one hour period in which any of the other players may dispute the decision. They do this by typing “Dispute:” followed by a reference to the Judgement into the voting thread. Players other than the Judge then have one hour to each type either “I agree with Judgement...” or “I disagree with Judgement...” followed by a reference to the Judgement. If no one disputes the decision within an hour or a single player other than the Judge agrees then the decision comes into effect. This process is called invoking Judgment. Otherwise, i.e. a player disputed the Judgement and all the other players who expressed an opinion within one hour from the dispute unanimously disagreed with the Judge’s decision, the Judge is overruled. If a Judge’s Judgment is overruled, then the player preceding the Judge in the order of Rule 201 becomes the new Judge for the Point of Order, and so on, except that no player is to be Judge during his or her own turn or during the turn of a team-mate. Unless a Judge is overruled, one Judge settles all questions arising from the game until the next turn is begun, including questions as to his or her own legitimacy and jurisdiction as Judge. If the Judge has not invoked Judgement by the end of the day, they forfeit their position as Judge on that Point of Order to the player preceding them in the order of days, excluding the player who’s allocated day it is or one of their teammates. The same applies for the new Judge. Any proposed rule-change involved in a dispute is voted on in the usual fashion, but if approved whilst still awaiting Judgement, the rule is not taken into effect until all the related Judgements are invoked. This has precedence over Rule 206 . All other actions under dispute are delayed until all relevant Judgements are invoked. A point of order may not be raised against a proposed rule-change for which voting has been completed but the rule-change has not yet come into effect. Multiple Points of Order may be brought up simultaneously. No player may have more than three active points of order at any one time. New Judges are not bound by the decisions of old Judges. New Judges may, however, settle only those questions on which the players currently disagree and that affect the completion of the turn in which Judgment was invoked. All decisions by Judges shall be in accordance with all the rules then in effect; but when the rules are silent, inconsistent, or unclear on the point at issue, then the Judge shall consider game-custom and the spirit of the game before applying other standards.

notes.author: Ben
notes.content: In non-correspondence games, the initial total is 100.

text: The winner is the first player to achieve 200 (positive) points.
Each player always has exactly one vote.

notes.author: Ben
notes.content:
This yields an integer between 0 and 10 for the first player, with the upper limit increasing by
one each turn; more points are awarded for more popular proposals.

text:
After completion of the vote the proposer adds the following number of points to their total
(max{ 10, number of the highest numbered existing rule-290})×number of “Vote: Yes” votes total number of votes cast.

notes.author: Ben
notes.content: As an example of a player adjusting another players score they should write “Ben P: 150 (+4)”

notes.author: Ben
notes.content: As an example of a player adjusting their own score they should write “150 (+4)”.

text:
If the number of points of any player changes at any time they, must announce their new total
followed by the change in parenthesis in the Telegram points thread. If anyone’s total is not
correct anyone else may correct it.

If and when rule-changes can be adopted without unanimity, the players who vote against winning
proposals shall receive 10 points each.

notes.author: Ben
notes.content: The turn order of alphabetical by surname was taken from Suber’s original rules.

text:
Each player is allocated one day a week. These days are
Chris B Monday
Dave M Tuesday
Ben P Wednesday
Alex T Thursday
Alex W Friday
Any message posted in the voting thread on a Saturday or Sunday is to be considered void. All players begin with zero points.

All players must always abide by all the rules then in effect, in the form in which they are then in
effect. The rules in the Initial Set are in effect whenever a game begins. The Initial Set consists of
Rules 101-118 (immutable) and 201-215 (mutable).

notes.author: Ben
notes.content:
Rule 214 stipulates that disputed rules do not come into effect until the relevant Judgement is
invoked.

text: An adopted rule-change takes full effect at the moment of the completion of the vote that adopted it. This is subject to Rule 214.

Rule-changes that transmute immutable rules into mutable rules may be adopted if and only if
the vote is unanimous among the eligible voters. Transmutation shall not be implied, but must be
stated explicitly in a proposal to take effect.

Whatever is not prohibited or regulated by a rule is permitted and unregulated, with the sole
exception of changing the rules, which is permitted only when a rule or set of rules explicitly or
implicitly permits it.

There must always be at least one mutable rule. The adoption of rule-changes must never become
completely impermissible.

Initially rules in the 100’s are immutable and rules in the 200’s are mutable. Rules subsequently
enacted or transmuted (that is, changed from immutable to mutable or vice versa) may be im-mutable or mutable regardless of their numbers, and rules in the Initial Set may be transmuted
regardless of their numbers.

notes.author: Ben
notes.content: Proper submissions are then voted on in accordance with Rule 113.

notes.author: Ben
notes.content:
There need not be any proposal on a given day. If a proposal is not submitted before 7pm, the
ability to submit a proposal is forfeited for that day.

text: Players may only propose rule-changes on their allocated day. The rule-change must be submitted in the sense of Rule 107 before 8pm on their allocated day to be considered proper. Only the first rule change submitted on a given day is considered proper. A Nomic day comprises the hours 7am-9am and 5:30pm-11pm on a day of the week allocated to a player in the sense of Rule 201. In the rules, the term 'day' shall be understood to mean 'Nomic day' unless specified otherwise. The names of days of the week specify calendar days, rather than Nomic days, unless stated otherwise. All posts in the voting thread outside of a Nomic day are considered void, including those of the form specified in Rule 214. Any period of time specified in the rules in units of hours and/or minutes, and without reference to times of the clock, shall be considered to exclude time outside of Nomic days, unless stated otherwise. That is, such a period only ends when the specified time has elapsed since the period began, not counting time outside of Nomic days. This rule does not regulate messages within the points thread, discussion thread or privately between individuals.
At no time may there be more than 25 mutable rules.

The state of affairs that constitutes winning may not be altered from achieving n points to any other
state of affairs. The magnitude of n and the means of earning points may be changed, and rules
that establish a winner when play cannot continue may be enacted and (while they are mutable)
be amended or repealed.

Players may discuss any topics with any other player(s) without the knowledge of the remaining
players. The Telegram discussion thread may be used for any purposes, but messages may not be
deleted or edited in any of the voting, points or discussion threads.

No rule-change may take effect earlier than the moment of the completion of the vote that adopted
it, even if its wording explicitly states otherwise. No rule-change may have retroactive application.

1. Each proposed rule-change shall be given a number for reference. The numbers shall begin with
301, and each rule-change proposed in the proper way shall receive the next successive integer,
whether or not the proposal is adopted.
2. If a rule is enacted, it receives the number of the proposal to enact it. If a rule is repealed and reenacted, it receives the number of the proposal to reenact it. If a rule is amended or transmuted, it receives the number of the proposal to amend or transmute it. If an amendment is amended or repealed, the entire rule of which it is a part receives the number of the proposal to amend or repeal the amendment.
3. When paragraph 2 would cause the number of a single proposal to be given to multiple rules, these rules shall instead be given consecutive numbers, starting with the number of the proposal. The affected rules shall be given these numbers in the order in which the proposal would first cause paragraph 2 to be invoked for each rule. If such a proposal is enacted, the following proposal shall be given the number succeeding the highest number assigned to a rule due to the enactment, rather than the number specified in paragraph 1.

All rule-changes proposed in the proper way shall be voted on. They will be adopted if and only if
they receive the required number of votes.
When a proposed rule-change is defeated, the player who proposed it loses 10 points.

A player always has the option to forfeit the game rather than continue to play or incur a game
penalty. No penalty worse than losing, in the judgment of the player to incur it, may be imposed.

If two or more mutable rules conflict with one another, or if two or more immutable rules conflict
with one another, then the rule with the lowest ordinal number takes precedence.
If at least one of the rules in conflict explicitly says of itself that it defers to another rule (or type of
rule) or takes precedence over another rule (or type of rule), then such provisions shall supersede
the numerical method for determining precedence.
If two or more rules claim to take precedence over one another or to defer to one another, then
the numerical method again governs.

notes.author: Ben
notes.content: Proper submissions are defined in Rule 202.

notes.author: Ben
notes.content: A player need not vote on any given proposal. Players may abstain by not submitting a vote.

notes.author: Ben
notes.content: Rule 208 states that each player has exactly one vote.

text:
Immediately after a proposal is submitted in the proper fashion, players may cast their vote(s)
within the Telegram voting thread. A vote is cast by replying with either the message “Vote: Yes”
or “Vote: No” to support or disagree with the proposal. A vote may not be withdrawn. Any
messages sent after the player has already used their vote(s) are not counted towards the total.
Voting is completed at the end of the day the proposal was submitted. After this point players may
not vote on the proposal.
